questions.question: What is a computer network?
questions.explanation: Network: multiple computers linked. Purpose: share files, printers, internet. Types: LAN, WAN, MAN. Size: 2 to millions. Technology: wired or wireless. Importance: modern computing foundation.

questions.question: What is a LAN?
questions.explanation: LAN: computers in small area. Range: typically one building. Speed: fast (Gbps). Technology: Ethernet, WiFi common. Examples: office, school, home. Advantage: low latency.

questions.question: What is a WAN?
questions.explanation: WAN: networks across cities/countries. Range: very large. Speed: slower than LAN. Technology: leased lines, satellite. Examples: Internet, branches. Challenge: higher latency.

questions.question: What is the Internet?
questions.explanation: Internet: interconnected networks worldwide. Foundation: TCP/IP protocol. History: ARPANET beginning. Scale: billions devices. Access: ISP connection needed. Impact: transformed communication.

questions.question: What is bandwidth?
questions.explanation: Bandwidth: maximum data rate. Measured: bits per second (bps). Analogy: water pipe size. Types: download/upload. Importance: network speed. Limit: shared resource.

questions.question: What is latency?
questions.explanation: Latency: time to send data. Measured: milliseconds (ms). Impact: affects responsiveness. Causes: distance, congestion. Lower: better for real-time. Critical: online gaming, video calls.

questions.question: What is throughput?
questions.explanation: Throughput: practical speed achieved. vs Bandwidth: actual vs theoretical. Measured: bps. Factors: network conditions, congestion. Reality: typically less than bandwidth. Importance: real-world metric.

questions.question: What is a protocol?
questions.explanation: Protocol: standardized format. Purpose: enable interoperability. Examples: TCP/IP, HTTP, DNS. Layers: different levels exist. Importance: universal understanding. Benefits: compatibility.

questions.question: What is IPv4?
questions.explanation: IPv4: 32-bit addresses. Format: 192.168.1.1. Addresses: 4 billion possible. Problem: address exhaustion. Example: most internet today. Limitation: running out of addresses.

questions.question: What is IPv6?
questions.explanation: IPv6: 128-bit addresses. Format: 2001:db8::1. Addresses: vastly more than IPv4. Purpose: replace IPv4. Adoption: gradually increasing. Benefit: future-proof.
